title: The Costs of Cancer

content: Cancer isn’t fair. Having cancer costs a lot in more ways than one could imagine. Survivors may go through myriad losses throughout their journey. This may include the loss of their identity, security, emotional stability, a body part, their hair, and many others.

Cancer can also be financially expensive. When one has to go to doctors’ appointments or have surgeries or procedures, they will likely have to use sick or personal time from work. If they exhaust  leave time, their paycheck may be reduced or they may not get paid at all. If they’re an entrepreneur, they may not be able to meet the demands of their clients. This will impact their stream of income.

Some people may not have health coverage, so how are they supposed to pay for treatment and medicine? Maybe they’ll have to tap into their retirement plan, savings account, or the equity in their home.  Some may have to take out personal loans. Even if they have health insurance, they may still have to cover various copays for visits or medicine. With mounting medical bills and other living expenses, some survivors may be forced to file for bankruptcy or max out their credit cards.

content: It is very important that survivors and their families are able to not be stressed over how to pay for treatment, housing, transportation, copays, student loans, and general costs of living.
Here are some resources that may be helpful:
American Cancer Society – Lists various programs and resources to help with cancer-related expenses.
Cancercare.org – Provides free, professional support services and information to help people manage the emotional, practical, and financial challenges of cancer.
Living Beyond Breast Cancer – Provides one-time grants for basic living expenses to help decrease financial burden.
The DONNA Foundation – Gives financial assistance and support to those living with breast cancer and funds groundbreaking breast cancer research.

American Breast Cancer Foundation — Education, access, and financial assistance to aid in the early detection, treatment, and survival of breast cancer for underserved and uninsured individuals, regardless of age, race, or gender.

sections.heading: Pink Fund
content: – Improves the lives of people in treatment for breast cancer through household bill payments, community engagement, and education.

sections.heading: Cancer + Careers
content: – Helps more than 470,000 people each year – online, in print, and in person – with valuable information and resources via expert advice, interactive tools, and educational events.

Deferment for Cancer Treatment for Direct Loan, FFEL, and Perkins Loan Program Borrowers – Qualified borrowers may get a deferment on their qualifying loans while they are getting cancer treatment and for the 6 months after their treatment is over. The deferment has no fixed time limit.

Total and Permanent Disability (TPD) Discharge – If you are totally and permanently disabled, you may qualify for a TPD discharge of your federal student loans or TEACH Grant service obligation. If you receive a TPD discharge, you will no longer be required to repay your loans or complete your TEACH Grant service obligation.
